title: 109_s18
content:
The "Meeting Our Responsibility to Medicare Beneficiaries Act of 2005" includes provisions for negotiating fair prices for Medicare prescription drugs, eliminating the MA Regional Plan Stabilization Fund, and improving the Medicare program for beneficiaries. TITLE I--ELIMINATING SPECIAL INTEREST PREFERENCES

Sec. 201-207 focus on various aspects of improving Medicare coverage, including eliminating coverage gaps, requiring two prescription drug plans, waiving late enrollment penalties, transitioning dual eligible individuals, reducing Part B premiums, studying incentives for retiree coverage, and promoting transparency in employer subsidy payments. Sec. 101 specifically addresses negotiating fair prices for Medicare prescription drugs. The Secretary is granted authority to negotiate prices with manufacturers of covered part D drugs, in line with other Federal entities, to ensure quality care and cost containment. This authority must be used for covered part D drugs offered under fallback prescription drug plans. The Secretary has the authority to negotiate fair and affordable prices for covered part D drugs under prescription drug plans and MA-PD plans to reflect bulk purchasing power. The amendment made by this section will be effective as if it was included in the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. SEC. 102 eliminates the MA Regional Plan Stabilization Fund. Effective date is retroactive to the Medicare Prescription Drug Act of 2003. SEC. 103 applies risk adjustment for Medicare Advantage payments. Effective January 1, 2006, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will adjust payments to organizations under section 1853 of the Social Security Act based on risk adjustment factors to reflect the health status of enrollees compared to those in the original Medicare fee-for-service program. Payments must account for these differences to ensure accuracy. This is part of improving the Medicare program for beneficiaries by eliminating coverage gaps. The Social Security Act is being amended to adjust the annual out-of-pocket threshold for Medicare beneficiaries. This adjustment ensures accuracy in payments to organizations under section 1853, reflecting the health status of enrollees compared to original Medicare fee-for-service program. The Social Security Act is being amended to adjust the annual out-of-pocket threshold for Medicare beneficiaries, ensuring accuracy in payments to organizations under section 1853. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. SEC. 202 of the Social Security Act requires two prescription drug plans to avoid federal fallback. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. SEC. 203 of the Social Security Act amends Section 1860D-13(b) to waive the late enrollment penalty for Part D eligible individuals enrolling in a prescription drug plan before January 1, 2008. The amendment is effective as if included in the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. SEC. 204 focuses on improving the transition of full-benefit dual eligible individuals to Medicare drug benefit coverage. Beginning on January 1, 2006, full-benefit dual eligible individuals will transition from Medicaid to Medicare Part D coverage for prescription drugs to ensure continued access to necessary medications. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will oversee this 12-month period of transition. Adjustments will be made to state contributions as needed. The State or the District of Columbia must make additional payments under the Social Security Act to cover increased medical assistance costs during the transition period. SEC. 205. PART B PREMIUM REDUCTION. The Secretary will reduce the monthly premium rate for individuals enrolled in Medicare Part B each year to match reduced expenditures from the Federal Supplementary Medicare Insurance Trust Fund. SEC. 206. STUDY AND REPORT ON PROVIDING INCENTIVES TO PRESERVE RETIREE COVERAGE. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to determine additional incentives for employers to continue providing retirees with prescription drug coverage. The study will assess allowing employer costs for covered part D drugs for retirees to count towards the annual out-of-pocket threshold. A report with recommendations for legislation will be submitted to Congress by January 1, 2006.

SEC. 207. PROMOTING TRANSPARENCY IN EMPLOYER SUBSIDY PAYMENTS. The amendment to the Social Security Act requires the Secretary to disclose information about subsidy payments to sponsors of qualified prescription drug plans. This information will be made available to the public through the CMS website. The amendment made by this section will take effect as if included in the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003.
